prompt: Mark told Pete many lies about himself, which Pete included in his book. He should have been more skeptical.  In the sentence above, does "He" refer to "Mark"? Explain your choice.
response: Yes, "He" refers to "Mark". In the sentence, the pronoun "He" is used to refer to Mark, indicating that the speaker is addressing Mark and is giving an account or description of Mark's actions or behavior.

prompt: The mothers of Arthur and Celeste have come to the town to fetch them. They are very happy to have them back, but they scold them just the same because they ran away.  In the sentence above, does "them" refer to "mothers"? Explain your choice.
response: In this sentence, "them" refers to "mothers".   This is because "them" is a plural pronoun, and it is used to refer to a group of people, in this case, both "Arthur" and "Celeste". The sentence is saying that the mothers of both Arthur and Celeste have come to the town, so "them" is referring to the group of mothers, rather than just one mother.

prompt: Mark was close to Mr. Singer 's heels. He heard him calling for the captain, promising him, in the jargon everyone talked that night, that not one thing should be damaged on the ship except only the ammunition, but the captain and all his crew had best stay in the cabin until the work was over  In the sentence above, does "He" refer to "Mr. Singer"? Explain your choice.
response: The pronoun "He" in the sentence refers to "Mr. Singer".   The reason is that "He" is a subject pronoun, which is used to refer to a person who is performing an action or being addressed. In this case, the action is "promising" and the subject is "Mr. Singer".   The pronoun "He" is in the third person, indicating that it is referring to a person, specifically Mr. Singer, rather than a person performing the action.   This is a clear example of the use of "He" as a third-person pronoun, which is used to refer to a person who is performing an action or being addressed.

prompt: The pony behaved well, sir, and showed no vice; but at last he just threw up his heels and tipped the young gentleman into the thorn hedge. He wanted me to help him out, but I hope you will excuse me, sir, I did not feel inclined to do so.  In the sentence above, does "He" refer to "young gentleman"? Explain your choice.
response: In this sentence, "He" refers to "young gentleman".   The reason is that the pronoun "he" is used to refer to a male person, and in the context of the sentence, it is clear that the pony is a male animal. The sentence is likely referring to a male pony.   The phrase "young gentleman" is also a idiomatic expression meaning "a young man" or "a male person of good breeding". In this context, it is being used to describe the pony's age and sex.

prompt: I poured water from the bottle into the cup until it was full.  In the sentence above, does "it" refer to "the cup"? Explain your choice.
response: In this sentence, "it" refers to "the cup". This is because "it" is a pronoun, and pronouns typically refer to the object or subject of a sentence. In this case, "it" is a pronoun that is performing the action of pouring water from the bottle into the cup, so it's referring to the cup.  If "it" were to refer to "the cup" (as in "the cup is pouring water"), the sentence would be ambiguous, as it would be unclear which cup is being referred to.

prompt: Dan had to stop Bill from toying with the injured bird. He is very compassionate.  In the sentence above, does "He" refer to "Dan"? Explain your choice.
response: In the sentence, "He" refers to "Bill".   This is because the subject of the sentence is "Dan", and the pronoun "he" is used to refer to Dan because Dan is the one performing the action of stopping Bill from toying with the injured bird. In this context, "he" is a reflexive pronoun, which is used when the subject is the one performing the action, rather than the one being acted upon.

prompt: Sam Goodman 's biography of the Spartan general Xenophanes conveys a vivid sense of the difficulties he faced in his childhood.  In the sentence above, does "he" refer to "Goodman"? Explain your choice.
response: In the sentence, "he" refers to "Xenophanes". This is because the pronoun "he" is a third-person singular pronoun, which is used to refer to a male person or a general. In this context, the pronoun "he" is likely referring to the Spartan general Xenophanes, as it is the more grammatically correct and commonly used form of address for a general in ancient Greek.  In ancient Greek, the first-person singular pronoun is "io" (Ἰω), which is used to refer to the speaker or the subject of the sentence. Using "he" instead of "io" would be incorrect in this context.

prompt: Pam's parents came home and found her having sex with her boyfriend, Paul. They were furious about it.  In the sentence above, does "They" refer to "Pam's parents"? Explain your choice.

prompt: Bob paid for Charlie 's college education, but now Charlie acts as though it never happened. He is very hurt.  In the sentence above, does "He" refer to "Bob"? Explain your choice.

prompt: Billy cried because Toby wouldn't share his toy.  In the sentence above, does "his" refer to "Toby"? Explain your choice.
response: In the sentence, "his" refers to "Toby". This is because "his" is a possessive pronoun, indicating that the toy belongs to Toby. In this context, "his" is used to show that the toy is something that belongs to Toby, rather than something that belongs to Billy.  The possessive pronoun "his" is used when we are describing something that belongs to someone, and it is typically followed by the name of the person. So, in this case, "his" is used to emphasize that the toy belongs to Toby, and it's the correct choice to use in this context.

prompt: Emma did not pass the ball to Janie although she was open.  In the sentence above, does "she" refer to "Janie"? Explain your choice.
response: In the sentence "Emma did not pass the ball to Janie although she was open," the pronoun "she" refers to "Janie".   This is because "she" is an object pronoun, which refers to a noun that is receiving the action of the verb. In this case, "she" is an object of the verb "pass", indicating that Emma is the one doing the action of passing the ball to Janie.  So, "she" is used to describe Janie, the person receiving the action, whereas "Emma" is used to describe the one performing the action.  This is a common usage of object pronouns in English, where "she" is used to refer to the recipient of the action, whereas "it" or "them" would be used to refer to the doer of the action.

prompt: Sam's drawing was hung just above Tina's and it did look much better with another one below it.  In the sentence above, does "it" refer to "Sam's drawing"? Explain your choice.

prompt: After I saw Bill catching flies and pulling off their wings, I boxed his ears. prompt: Sir Clifford wants me to find him a new groom , about twenty or twenty-one, who knows his business. prompt: Since it was raining, I carried the newspaper over my backpack to keep it dry.  In the sentence above, does "it" refer to "The newspaper"? Explain your choice.

prompt: If the con artist has succeeded in fooling Sam , he would have gotten a lot of money.  In the sentence above, does "he" refer to "The con artist"? Explain your choice.

prompt: The boy continued to whip the pony , and eventually the pony threw him over. John laughed out quite loud. "Served him right," he said.  In the sentence above, does "him" refer to "pony"? Explain your choice.

The phrase "an old rag" is used to refer to the object, "the knife", as the subject of the sentence. The phrase "an old rag" is a noun phrase that functions as a noun, describing the type of material used to clean the knife.  So, "it" is a clear pronoun referring to "the knife", while "an old rag" is a noun phrase referring to the material used to clean the knife.

prompt: John hired Bill to take care of him .  In the sentence above, does "him" refer to "Bill"? Explain your choice.
response: In the sentence "John hired Bill to take care of him", "him" refers to "Bill".   The word "him" is a pronoun, and in this context, it is a reflexive pronoun, which means it is used to refer to the person who is being addressed. In this case, "him" is referring to Bill, indicating that John is addressing Bill.  Here's why:  * "Him" is a pronoun that is reflexive, meaning it is used to refer to the person who is the object of the action (in this case, "taking care of"). * The sentence structure "to take care of him" implies that John is addressing Bill, and therefore, "him" refers to Bill.  In contrast, "himself" would not make sense in this context, as it would imply that John is referring to himself.

prompt: Jane knocked on the door, and Susan answered it. She invited her to come out.  In the sentence above, does "She" refer to "Jane"? Explain your choice.
response: In the sentence, "She" refers to "Susan". The pronoun "She" is an object pronoun, which refers to the person or thing being addressed, in this case, Susan. It is used to show that the person performing the action (in this case, Jane knocking on the door) is the one being invited to leave.

prompt: The journalists interviewed the stars of the new movie. They were very persistent, so the interview lasted for a long time.  In the sentence above, does "They" refer to "The journalists"? Explain your choice.
response: The pronoun "They" in the sentence "The journalists interviewed the stars of the new movie" refers to "The journalists".   The word "They" is a plural pronoun, and in this context, it is referring to a group of people, specifically journalists. The sentence implies that multiple journalists were interviewing the stars of the movie, not a single journalist.

prompt: As Ollie carried Tommy up the long winding steps, his legs ached.  In the sentence above, does "his" refer to "Ollie"? Explain your choice.
response: In the sentence "As Ollie carried Tommy up the long winding steps, his legs ached," the pronoun "his" refers to "Ollie". This is because "his" is a possessive pronoun, indicating that the legs belong to Ollie.  The possessive form of the pronoun "his" is used to show that something belongs to the subject of the sentence, in this case, Ollie.

prompt: Carol believed that Rebecca regretted that she had stolen the watch.  In the sentence above, does "she" refer to "Rebecca"? Explain your choice.
response: In the sentence, "she" refers to "Rebecca". This is an example of a pronoun reference in a sentence, where a pronoun (in this case "she") is used to refer to a noun (in this case "Rebecca").  The use of "she" here indicates that the speaker is referring to Rebecca, implying that she is the one who stole the watch.

prompt: Bob paid for Charlie 's college education. He is very generous.  In the sentence above, does "He" refer to "Charlie"? Explain your choice.
response: In the sentence, "He" refers to "Charlie". The pronoun "He" is a third-person singular pronoun, which is used to refer to a person who is typically male. Since Charlie is a male, "He" is a suitable choice to refer to him in the context of paying for his college education.

prompt: All the buttons up the back of Dora 's plaid dress were buttoned outside-in. Maude should have thought to button her up; but no, she had left poor little Dora to do the best she could, alone.  In the sentence above, does "she" refer to "Dora"? Explain your choice.
response: In this sentence, "she" refers to "Maude." This is because the pronoun "she" is a third-person singular pronoun, which refers to a single person. In this context, "Maude" is the subject of the sentence, and the pronoun "she" is used to refer to her.  The use of "she" is also consistent with the context, where it is used to refer to an individual, in this case, Maude.

prompt: The table was piled high with food , and on the floor beside it there were crocks, baskets, and a five-quart pail of milk.  In the sentence above, does "it" refer to "floor"? Explain your choice.
response: In this sentence, "it" refers to "the floor".   The pronoun "it" is used to refer to the noun "floor" in this context, as indicated by the prepositional phrase "beside it". This is an example of an object pronoun, which is a pronoun that refers to a specific noun or object.

prompt: Mark was close to Mr. Singer 's heels. He heard him calling for the captain , promising him, in the jargon everyone talked that night, that not one thing should be damaged on the ship except only the ammunition, but the captain and all his crew had best stay in the cabin until the work was over.  In the sentence above, does "his" refer to "Mark"? Explain your choice.
response: In the sentence, "his" refers to "Mr. Singer". The use of "his" in the sentence is an example of possessive case, where the subject of the sentence is "Mr. Singer". In this context, "his" indicates that Mr. Singer is the owner or possessor of the ammunition.

prompt: The man lifted the boy onto his shoulders.  In the sentence above, does "his" refer to "The boy"? Explain your choice.
response: In the sentence, "his" refers to "The boy".   The possessive pronoun "his" is used to show that something belongs to him. In this context, the sentence is saying that the man lifted the boy onto his shoulders, which means the boy is being carried or supported by the man, and therefore, the man is the one who owns or has control over the boy.

prompt: Do you suppose that Peter is responsible for the captain ’s illness? Maybe he bribed the cook to put something in his food.  In the sentence above, does "his" refer to "Peter"? Explain your choice.
response: In the sentence, "his" refers to "Peter". The possessive form "his" is used to show ownership or possession, indicating that the food belongs to Peter. The pronoun "his" is used to refer to Peter, as it is a possessive adjective.  In the sentence, "his" is not referring to the captain, but rather to Peter, the cook. The phrase "to the captain" is a prepositional phrase that indicates the recipient of the food, and "his" is the possessive form used to indicate Peter's ownership or possession of the food.

prompt: The signs over the shops' doors had pictures that indicated what work was done inside. Although more and more people were learning how to read, each artisan still had signs, not wishing to lose a possible patron merely because he happened to be illiterate.  In the sentence above, does "he" refer to "patron"? Explain your choice.
response: The word "he" in the sentence refers to "patron".   The word "he" is an object pronoun, which is used to refer to an object or a person performing an action. In this sentence, "he" is used to refer to the patron, the person who is the object of the action (the person who is being referred to by the shop owner, presumably a patron).

prompt: Paul tried to call George on the phone, but he wasn't available.  In the sentence above, does "he" refer to "George"? Explain your choice.
response: In the sentence "Paul tried to call George on the phone, but he wasn't available," "he" refers to George. This is because "he" is a pronoun that is used to refer to the person that is doing the action of calling, in this case, Paul. Since Paul is the one trying to call George, "he" is the correct pronoun to use in this context.  If the sentence said "George was available", then "he" would refer to George, not Paul.

prompt: Sam's drawing was hung just above Tina's and it did look much better with another one above it.  In the sentence above, does "it" refer to "Sam's drawing"? Explain your choice.
response: In the sentence, "it" refers to "Sam's drawing". The pronoun "it" is a singular subject pronoun, referring to the subject of the sentence, which is "Sam's drawing". This is because "it" is a possessive pronoun that shows that "Sam's drawing" is the thing being referred to.

prompt: The table won't fit through the doorway because it is too wide.  In the sentence above, does "it" refer to "The table"? Explain your choice.
response: In the sentence "The table won't fit through the doorway because it is too wide," the pronoun "it" refers to "The table." This is because "it" is a pronoun, which is a word that replaces a noun in a sentence. In this case, "it" is performing the function of a definite article, which is "The" in this case.  So, "it" refers to "The table" because "The" is the definite article that is used to specify the noun "table" in the sentence.

prompt: Emma Emma's mother had died long ago, and her education had been managed by an excellent woman as governess.  In the sentence above, does "her" refer to "Emma's mother"? Explain your choice.
response: In the sentence, "her" refers to "Emma's mother". This is because the subject of the sentence is "Emma", and "her" is a possessive pronoun indicating that something belongs to Emma, specifically her mother.  When "her" is used in the possessive form, it refers to the subject that possesses the noun, in this case, "Emma's mother". This is a grammatical rule in English, where "her" is used to indicate that something belongs to Emma, rather than referring to Emma herself.  So, the sentence can be translated as: "Emma's mother had died long ago".

prompt: Bill passed the gameboy to John because his turn was next.  In the sentence above, does "his" refer to "John"? Explain your choice.
response: In the sentence, "his" refers to "John". This is because "his" is an object pronoun, which is used to refer to an object that is already possessive or indicates the owner of something. In this context, "his" is describing the person who is the owner of the Gameboy, John.

prompt: Of one thing Mark was sure. Harry knew much less than he did.  In the sentence above, does "he" refer to "Harry"? Explain your choice.
response: No, "he" in the sentence "Of one thing Mark was sure. Harry knew much less than he did" refers to "Mark". The pronoun "he" is referring to Mark because the subject of the sentence is "Mark", not "Harry".

prompt: Do you suppose that Peter is responsible for the captain ’s illness? Maybe he bribed the cook to put something in his food.  In the sentence above, does "his" refer to "the captain"? Explain your choice.
response: In the sentence, "his" refers to "the captain." This is because "his" is a possessive pronoun, which indicates that the noun it precedes is owned by or belongs to the person. In this case, "his" is used to show that the food was prepared or served by Peter, and it is his own food.  This usage is called a possessive pronoun, and "his" is the correct choice because it shows that Peter is the one who prepared the food, not the captain.

prompt: What about the time you cut up tulip bulbs in the hamburgers because you thought they were onions?  In the sentence above, does "they" refer to "hamburgers"? Explain your choice.
response: In this sentence, "they" refers to "hamburgers". The pronoun "they" is used as a singular subject, and since the subject is a singular noun (hamburgers), the singular form "they" is used to refer to it.

prompt: Fred covered his eyes with his hands , because the wind was blowing sand around. He lowered them when the wind stopped.  In the sentence above, does "them" refer to "His eyes"? Explain your choice.
response: In the sentence, "them" refers to "his eyes". This is because the pronoun "them" is a reflexive pronoun, which is used to refer to the person or people affected by the action of the verb in the previous sentence. In this case, "him" is a subject pronoun, referring to the person who is covering his eyes, and "them" is a reflexive pronoun, referring to the eyes that are affected by the action.  In the sentence, the phrase "the wind was blowing sand around" is a descriptive phrase, and "him" is the subject of the sentence. So, "him" is referring to the person who is affected by the action of the verb in the previous sentence.   The sentence is describing Fred's actions, and "him" is the correct choice because it is the person affected by the action, not the eyes.

prompt: Sid explained his theory to Mark but he couldn't understand him.  In the sentence above, does "he" refer to "Sid"? Explain your choice.
response: In this sentence, "he" refers to "Sid". The pronoun "he" is a third-person singular pronoun, which means it is used to refer to a single individual. Since Sid is the subject of the sentence, "he" is the appropriate pronoun to use to refer to him.  So, the sentence "Sid explained his theory to Mark but he couldn't understand him" implies that Sid is the one explaining the theory to Mark, but it doesn't directly imply that Sid is the one who is being understood.

prompt: Tom gave Ralph a lift to school so he wouldn't have to drive alone.  In the sentence above, does "he" refer to "Ralph"? Explain your choice.
response: In the sentence, "he" refers to "Ralph." This is because "he" is a pronoun that is typically used to refer to a male person, as in the sentence "She gave a hug to her brother." In this context, "he" is being used to refer to Ralph, indicating that he is the person who received the lift to school.  This is an example of a pronoun reference, where the pronoun is being used to refer to a specific person who is not explicitly mentioned in the sentence.

prompt: When my parents died, I was not earning enough to keep myself or my crippled sister Nelly , and without our kind mistress , we would have gone to the poorhouse. Nelly calls her her angel and she has good right to do so. her  In the sentence above, does "her" refer to "mistress"? Explain your choice.
response: In the sentence, "her" refers to "mistress".   This is because "her" is a possessive pronoun, which indicates that the subject of the sentence (Nelly) is a woman and owns something. Since the subject is a woman, the possessive pronoun "her" is used to show ownership.  In this context, "her" refers to the mistress, which is likely a reference to a person who is Nelly's lover or a woman with whom Nelly has a close relationship.  The phrase "without our kind mistress" also supports this interpretation, as it implies that the narrator and Nelly are dependent on the mistress for their well-being, and without her, they would be in a difficult situation.

prompt: After I saw Bill catching flies and pulling off their wings, I boxed his ears. I showed the master the flies, some crushed and some crawling about helpless, and I showed him the wings on the window sill. I never saw him so angry before; but as Bill was still howling and whining, like the coward that he was, he did not give him any more punishment of that kind, but set him up on a stool for the rest of the afternoon, and said that he should not go out to play for that week.  In the sentence above, does "he" refer to "the master"? Explain your choice.
response: In the sentence, "he" refers to "the master".   This is because the pronoun "he" is a third-person singular pronoun, which is used to refer to a person who is not yet referred to by a specific name. In this case, "the master" is the noun that "he" is referring to, and the sentence is addressing the master.

prompt: Ann asked Mary what time the library closes, because she had forgotten.  In the sentence above, does "she" refer to "Mary"? Explain your choice.
